description: Prominent Trump supporters have come out against any US involvement in the conflict, warning of a potential rupture within the movement, while members from the former president's inner circle push for regime change in Tehran.

Six months later, Bayrou is still France's PM – and not finished
description: With no majority to back him in the Assemblée Nationale, Prime Minister François Bayrou has governed from a precarious position. He has held on, so far, thanks to a fragile agreement with the Socialists to re-examine the unpopular 2023 reform of the pensions system.

headline: X allowed ads to be targeted according to political criteria, a prohibited practice
description: The targeting method, which is banned in Europe, with rare exceptions, by the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), continues to be used on Elon Musk's social network, according to a study by the NGO AI Forensics.

headline: For European women's basketball, the WNBA's rise comes at a cost
description: The North American league's calendar has forced some European players to forgo the EuroBasket continental tournament opening Wednesday.

headline: Iran-Israel: 'Preventive war and regime change are rarely met with success'
description: Fundamentally committed to international law, Europe is struggling to deal with the contradictions the US imposes on it, in a world where force increasingly prevails, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

The US refusal to intervene in Syria in 2013: A French trauma
description: 'The Transatlantic Divorce' (3/5). On August 31, 2013, as French warplanes were en route to Syria to launch a joint operation with the US against the regime of Bashar al-Assad, which had used chemical weapons against its own people, Barack Obama decided to delay, leaving France alone and powerless.

headline: The failure of Obama's 'leading from behind' in Libya
description: 'The Transatlantic Divorce' (2/5). Elected on the promise of no longer sending American troops to the Middle East, President Barack Obama allowed France and the UK to lead the Libyan operation, which resulted in Muammar Gaddafi's fall. He emerged deeply frustrated by the shortcomings of his European allies.

headline: UK government reverses course and launches national inquiry into 'grooming gangs'
description: After a damning audit by a senior civil servant, Prime Minister Keir Starmer confirmed that the networks of sexual predators who operated for decades in the United Kingdom would be subject to a public inquiry.
